sent_14: According to the AP news agency, the assault on Ukrainian House started after an estimated 200 police were seen entering the building and speculation spread that they were preparing to disperse demonstrators.
sent_15: The protesters later in the night formed a corridor on the steps of the building to allow security forces inside to leave.
sent_16: According to the AFP news agency, all had left over a few hours.
sent_17: During a visit to Warsaw on January 25, European Union President Herman Van Rompuy condemned the "use of force and brutality by the Ukrainian authorities against demonstrators."
sent_18: Earlier, Ukrainian authorities confirmed one more antigovernment protester has died as a tense standoff between protesters and riot police continues in Kyiv and unrest spreads throughout the country.
sent_19: Kyiv's city health department said the man died on January 25 of injuries sustained in violent clashes earlier this week.
sent_2: Arseniy Yatsenyuk said the opposition was ready to take on responsibility but added the "people will determine the power in Ukraine."
sent_20: His death brings to four the number of confirmed fatalities since violent clashes began in the capital six days ago.
sent_21: Also on January 25, Human Rights Watch (HRW) released a statement saying it was "gravely concerned" about the life and safety of missing activist Dmytro Bulatov, who has been a prominent figure in antigovernment protests.
sent_22: The rights organization said Bulatov told his wife he was going to a meeting at 7 p.m. local time on January 23.
sent_23: That was the last contact anyone had with him.
sent_24: Friends and relatives said his cell phone ceased working the next morning and his car is missing.
sent_25: HRW cites another opposition activist as saying Bulatov had been receiving threatening text messages for weeks.
sent_26: Meanwhile, the situation was mostly calm in Kyiv early on January 25 after sporadic clashes overnight.
sent_27: Protesters occupied the Energy Ministry building, but left after several hours.
sent_28: Police accused protesters of holding two police officers captive in Kyiv's city hall which protesters have occupied, and demanded their immediate release.

sent_3: Earlier, Yanukovych offered Yatsenyuk the post of prime minister and Klitschko the post of deputy prime minister for humanitarian affairs to defuse protests that are now spreading from Kyiv to other parts of the country.
sent_30: A protester shouts to riot police in front of a barricade during an antigovernment protest in downtown Kyiv.
sent_31: Interior Minister Vitaliy Zakharchenko said efforts to end the crisis peacefully without the use of force remain "futile."
sent_32: Zakharchenko accused the mainstream opposition of failing to control radicals and claimed protesters were "hoarding firearms" at the Kyiv city hall.
sent_33: However, in an exclusive interview with the Russian news agency ITAR-TASS, Ukraine's Defense Minister Pavel Lebedev ruled out using the country's military to resolve the protests.
sent_34: "The army will strictly follow the constitution and laws of Ukraine that clearly lay out its role, functions and tasks," Lebedev said on January 26.
sent_35: He also rejected claims that the military would intervene in the current conflict, calling such comments "provocations."
sent_36: Meanwhile, Ukraine's richest man, Rinat Akhmetov -- a key backer of President Viktor Yanukovych -- has said the use of force was "unacceptable."
sent_37: On January 25, protesters stormed the regional administration offices in the town of Vinnytsia, southwest of Kyiv.
sent_38: Protesters are already occupying government offices in several cities in western Ukraine.
sent_39: Outside the country, Pope Francis has called for an end to violence in Ukraine and urged "constructive dialogue" between Ukraine's authorities and the people.
sent_4: Yanukovych also agreed to consider changes to the constitution, which currently gives most powers to the president.
sent_40: "I am close to Ukraine in prayer, in particular to those who have lost their lives in recent days and to their families," he said on January 26.
sent_41: The pontiff appealed for the "spirit of peace and search for the common good" to prevail in Ukraine.
sent_42: EU Enlargement Commissioner Stefan Fuele, in Kyiv to try to mediate a solution, urged the government to take concrete steps to halt the violence.
sent_43: Fuele met on January 24 with both Yanukovych and the three main opposition leaders.
sent_44: Yanukovych has promised to reshuffle his government, an amnesty for detained protesters, and amendments to laws restricting protests whose passing last week triggered the recent clashes.
sent_45: But he also said on January 24 he would use all legal measures to end protests.
sent_46: "First of all, I don't want people to be frozen in the streets.
sent_47: They suffer and they don't know how to get out of this situation.
sent_48: And I will repeat myself -- if we can do it in a good way to stop the radicals we will, if not, we will use all measures under the law.
sent_49: But it's all for the people.
sent_5: "We are not throwing out the proposal, but we are not accepting it, either.
sent_50: There is no other way," Yanukovych said.
sent_51: The opposition had dismissed Yanukovych's promises and wants him to resign.
sent_52: Opposition leader Vitali Klitschko said "to change just the ministers in not enough.".
sent_53: "People want to change the rules because they are already tired of living without rules.
sent_54: Everybody is saying 'no.'
sent_55: You can buy any court, you can't find justice in our country.
sent_56: The system is totally corrupt.
sent_57: And that is why people right now are not happy," Klitschko said.
sent_58: The antigovernment protests began after Yanukovych unexpectedly pulled back from a long-negotiated agreement on closer ties with the European Union in late November.
sent_59: They have been fueled by what activists say is widespread government corruption, abuse of power, and the violation of human rights.
sent_6: We are conducting serious consultations among three opposition forces," Yatsenyuk said later at a news conference in Kyiv.
sent_7: "To be honest we were not happy about the proposal.
sent_8: I am perfectly aware about what is going on in the country now.
sent_9: The country is on the verge of bankruptcy.

sent_16: We can say what we like and be heard.
sent_17: In Russia it’s impossible to have such a platform – from here we can tell the whole world what is happening in Russia.”

sent_2: “It’s basically just an ordinary, everyday photo.”

sent_21: She grabbed a few essentials, told friends on a phone she thought was bugged that she was leaving for St Petersburg, and instead travelled by minibus to Belarus.
sent_22: At Minsk airport she waited until the last possible moment to buy a ticket for fear she would be stopped from leaving, then boarded a flight for Kiev.
sent_23: “I held my breath until that plane took off,” she said.
sent_24: Kurnosova was arrested countless times at protest rallies in Russia, spending many nights in police cells, since the days 20 years ago when she was on St Petersburg city council and Putin worked in the mayor’s office.
sent_25: He was such a “dull, insignificant” figure that she has few strong memories of the man whose regime she accuses of driving her from homeland, along with more than 100 other Kremlin critics whom she said have recently relocated from Russia to Ukraine.
sent_26: “It’s impossible to change things in Russia through elections now and by taking part you are only legitimising the corrupt system,” Kurnosova said.
sent_27: “We should form an opposition abroad, linking groups in Ukraine with Russian communities in places like the Baltic states and Moldova so that, when the time comes, we have a transparent, functioning system to put in place [in Russia].”
sent_28: Kurnosova sets no store by Putin’s huge approval ratings, saying most Russians dare to give pollsters only “politically correct” answers.

sent_32: “If they alter their trajectory, it may be possible to change Russia without bloodshed,” Kurnosova added, “but I only give that a 5 per cent chance.”
sent_33: For Kurnosova, like most of her compatriots and for world leaders, the idea of Russia collapsing into bloody chaos is the stuff of nightmares.
sent_34: For the 250,000 or so Chechens now living abroad after fleeing war with Russia, however, such a scenario may seem like the only way to finally win independence and return home.
sent_35: “The last war of the Russian empire is happening here in Ukraine, which is an outpost or a fortress of European civilisation against Russia,” Okuyeva said.
sent_36: “When Russia loses, it will break up, and the Urals, Siberia and Chechnya and the North Caucasus will be free.”

sent_4: Clad in camouflage and carrying Kalashnikovs and grenade launchers, Osmayev and Okuyeva are pictured somewhere in eastern Ukraine, where they are among a growing number of Chechens now fighting Russian-backed separatists.
sent_40: “We see messages online saying they are looking for us and we have information that they are active here,” Osmayev said, confirming that enemies from Russia’s bloodiest domestic conflict were now hunting each other in eastern Ukraine.
sent_41: “We are looking for them too,” he added.
sent_42: “We are trying to make sure we get them first.”
sent_5: Moreover, the photo was taken just days after Osmayev’s release from jail in Odessa, where he had been held for nearly three years on suspicion of plotting to blow up Russian president Vladimir Putin – charges that were eventually quashed.
sent_6: “If Ukraine loses this war it will be regarded as a victory for the Russian empire.
sent_7: But if Ukraine wins it will bring freedom for Chechnya and for Russia itself much closer,” Osmayev told The Irish Times by phone from the front line.
sent_8: “And we are ready to fight to the end.”
sent_9: For many Ukrainians, last winter’s revolution was ultimately a struggle to end centuries of Russian domination; and Moscow’s furious, bloody and costly reaction to Kiev’s westward tilt revealed the strength of Putin’s hostility towards it.

sent_33: For Kurnosova, like most of her compatriots and for world leaders, the idea of Russia collapsing into bloody chaos is the stuff of nightmares.
sent_34: For the 250,000 or so Chechens now living abroad after fleeing war with Russia, however, such a scenario may seem like the only way to finally win independence and return home.
sent_35: “The last war of the Russian empire is happening here in Ukraine, which is an outpost or a fortress of European civilisation against Russia,” Okuyeva said.
sent_36: “When Russia loses, it will break up, and the Urals, Siberia and Chechnya and the North Caucasus will be free.”
sent_37: On the front line, Osmayev said “thousands” of Chechens in Europe would fight for Ukraine if Kiev legalised their status and gave them citizenship.
sent_38: For now, Okuyeva added, most of the Chechens on Ukraine’s side are acting as advisers to the country’s military and volunteer battalions.
sent_39: The separatists in eastern Ukraine have their own warriors from Chechnya, loyal to its Kremlin-backed warlord Ramzan Kadyrov, including a “death battalion” with orders to capture or kill Chechens fighting for Kiev.
sent_4: Clad in camouflage and carrying Kalashnikovs and grenade launchers, Osmayev and Okuyeva are pictured somewhere in eastern Ukraine, where they are among a growing number of Chechens now fighting Russian-backed separatists.
sent_40: “We see messages online saying they are looking for us and we have information that they are active here,” Osmayev said, confirming that enemies from Russia’s bloodiest domestic conflict were now hunting each other in eastern Ukraine.
sent_41: “We are looking for them too,” he added.
sent_42: “We are trying to make sure we get them first.”
sent_5: Moreover, the photo was taken just days after Osmayev’s release from jail in Odessa, where he had been held for nearly three years on suspicion of plotting to blow up Russian president Vladimir Putin – charges that were eventually quashed.
sent_6: “If Ukraine loses this war it will be regarded as a victory for the Russian empire.
sent_7: But if Ukraine wins it will bring freedom for Chechnya and for Russia itself much closer,” Osmayev told The Irish Times by phone from the front line.
sent_8: “And we are ready to fight to the end.”
sent_9: For many Ukrainians, last winter’s revolution was ultimately a struggle to end centuries of Russian domination; and Moscow’s furious, bloody and costly reaction to Kiev’s westward tilt revealed the strength of Putin’s hostility towards it.

sent_0: KIEV (Reuters) - Ukraine's parliament voted on Saturday to remove President Viktor Yanukovich from office, hours after he abandoned his Kiev office to protesters and denounced what he described as a coup.
sent_1: The apparent toppling of the pro-Russian leader looks likely to dramatically alter the future of the former Soviet republic of 46 million people, pulling it closer to Europe and away from Moscow's orbit.
sent_10: I feel sorrow for my country," he told UBR television.
sent_11: Despite his defiance, the dismantling of his authority seemed all but complete with his cabinet promising a transition to a new government, the police declaring themselves behind the protesters and his jailed arch adversary expected to go free.
sent_12: Among a series of acts aimed at removing his government, parliament voted to free jailed former prime minister Yulia Tymoshenko.
sent_13: Her daughter said Tymoshenko was already free under Ukrainian law but still in the hospital where she has been held for treatment.

sent_17: "Yanukovich will never be back."

sent_27: "The organs of the Interior Ministry have crossed to the side of the protesters, the side of the people," new Interior Minister Arsen Avakov told Ukraine's Channel 5 TV.
sent_28: Yanukovich, who enraged much of the population by turning away from the European Union to cultivate closer relations with Russia three months ago, made sweeping concessions in the deal brokered by European diplomats on Friday after days of pitched fighting in Kiev that saw police snipers gun down protesters.
sent_29: But the deal, which called for early elections by the end of the year, was not enough to satisfy pro-Europe demonstrators on Independence Square, known as the Maidan, or "Euro-Maidan", who want Yanukovich out immediately in the wake of the bloodletting.
sent_3: The Ukrainian parliament, which decisively abandoned Yanukovich after loyalists defected, declared the president constitutionally unable to carry out his duties and set an early election for May 25.

title: Ukraine parliament removes Yanukovich, who flees Kiev in "coup"

sent_0: The SMM monitored the implementation of the “Package of measures for the implementation of the Minsk agreements”.
sent_1: Its monitoring was restricted by the parties and security considerations*.
sent_10: The interlocutor claimed that while the situation was calmer recently, his subordinates reported that “DPR” intelligence gathering and reconnaissance patrols in the area were contributing to a tense atmosphere.
sent_11: On 26 September the SMM observed a convoy consisting of 15 cargo trucks marked as humanitarian convoy belonging to the Rinat Akhmetov Foundation, which was leaving “DPR”-controlled Donetsk city travelling freely through the “DPR” checkpoint in a southern direction.
sent_12: The SMM also observed in Donetsk city five cargo trucks escorted by a “DPR” “military police” vehicle, moving west.
sent_13: In government-controlled Marinka (23km south-west of Donetsk) the SMM talked to several interlocutors, who expressed a strong opinion about the need for Ukrainian Armed Forces to open a passage across the contact line for the residents from the nearby villages to travel on the Kurakhove-Donetsk route.
sent_14: Following that the SMM discussed the issue with the civil-military co-operation officers of the Ukrainian Armed Forces in Marinka, who stated the Anti-Terrorist Operation Headquarters was considering the idea of opening the requested passage corridor.
sent_15: The SMM spoke to shop-owners in government-controlled Krasnohorivka (21km west of Donetsk) who indicated that they had to acquire from the city administration a permit with the list of products they were bringing through government checkpoints, and that there was a limit for the amount of goods per crossing.
sent_16: The deputy commander at the closest relevant government checkpoint near Heorhiivka (26km south-west of Donetsk) confirmed to the SMM that local businesses indeed had to obtain a permit in order to transport goods through the checkpoint.
sent_17: On 26 September the SMM observed long lines of civilian vehicles at armed checkpoints waiting to cross both into governmental-controlled and “DPR”-controlled areas.
sent_18: While driving on H20 highway the SMM recorded at a Ukrainian Armed Forces checkpoint near Berezove (31km south-west of Donetsk) a queue of 160 vehicles waiting to cross into government-controlled area.
sent_19: Approaching a government checkpoint near government-controlled Volnovakha (52km south-west of Donetsk) the SMM noted 90 vehicles waiting to cross into the governmental-controlled area, and 432 vehicles queued to move north, into the “DPR”-controlled area.
sent_2: The situation remained largely calm in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions with only sparse ceasefire violations recorded by the SMM.
sent_20: At a checkpoint near government-controlled Maiorsk (44km north of Donetsk) the SMM counted 370 vehicles waiting to enter the government-controlled area, while 16 buses, 300 pedestrians, and 30 vehicles were queued to enter the “DPR”-controlled area.
sent_21: At the government checkpoint near Zaitseve (50km north-east of Donetsk) the SMM observed at least 79 vehicles waiting to move into the “DPR”-controlled area and 373 vehicles waiting to travel into the government-controlled area.
sent_22: At the “Shakhtarski Zori” health resort in Proletarskyi district of “DPR”-controlled Donetsk city, the SMM observed on 27 September a civilian mini-van with Russian Federation Krasnodar region licence plates.
sent_23: The licence plate number was fixed on a factory-made frame carrying the Russian inscription “FSB of Russian Federation”.
sent_24: As the SMM was about to depart from the facility, a male wearing the Russian new-style camouflage uniform without  any rank, insignia or patches, came out of the resort building and took a photograph or video of the leaving SMM vehicle, and made written notes.
sent_25: The SMM observed an overall calm security situation in the Luhansk region with few ceasefire violations.
sent_26: On 26 September, from a stationary position north of government-controlled Trokhizbenka (33km north-west of Luhansk), the SMM heard in short intervals a couple of small-arms shots, three undetermined explosions, and sounds of two outgoing 82mm mortar rounds.
sent_27: All sounds were assessed as originating from the nearby Ukrainian Armed Forces military training area, and the SMM was informed in advance by Ukrainian Armed Forces that live-fire exercises would be conducted at this specific training facility.
sent_28: During their interaction with the SMM both Ukrainian Armed Forces personnel and armed “Lugansk People’s Republic (“LPR”) members made mutual allegations of small-arms ceasefire violations.
sent_29: “LPR” members told the SMM that they were targeted on 25 September in the area of “LPR”-controlled Pryshyb (33km north-west of Luhansk), and Krasnyi Lyman (30km north-west of Luhansk).
sent_3: The SMM observed considerable queues of civilian vehicles waiting at checkpoints to cross both into government-controlled and non-government controlled areas.
sent_30: The Ukrainian Armed Forces interlocutors stated they came under fire at the checkpoint near government-controlled Troitske (69km west of Luhansk).
sent_31: On 27 September the SMM enquired on prices and the availability of goods at two trading places in “LPR”-controlled Luhansk city.
sent_32: While both markets were well equipped with food and sanitary items the SMM concluded that the cost of basic products increased by an average 5% during the month of September.
sent_33: The SMM interlocutors at the markets claimed that the rise in prices was owed to the fact that they had to pay at the checkpoints for transporting the supplies into “LPR”-controlled areas.
sent_34: The SMM observed that the Russian Rouble was used as the primary currency in the market transactions, rather than the Ukrainian Hryvnia.
sent_35: The SMM monitored on 26 September a local ceasefire regime, through which it facilitated power line repair works near “LPR”-controlled Obozne (18km north of Luhansk).
sent_36: The SMM heard two explosions occurring within an interval of three hours.
sent_37: A repair worker of the electrical company informed the SMM that a member of the “LPR” demining team had been injured by an anti-personnel mine in the first explosion, and transported to the hospital.
sent_38: The second explosion, according to the interlocutor, was a controlled detonation of unexploded ordnance (UXO) performed by the “LPR” demining team during the demining process that preceded the repairs.
sent_39: The SMM re-visited on 26 September three “DPR” heavy weapons holding areas.
sent_4: The SMM recorded a small number of ceasefire violations in the Donetsk region, where the security situation was otherwise relatively calm.
sent_40: At one of the sites the “DPR” armed member on guard did not allow access to the SMM for 50 minutes, until receiving permission from his superiors.
sent_41: One anti-tank gun (MT-12 Rapira , 10mm) was missing at this location.
sent_42: On 27 September the SMM visited another two “DPR” heavy weapons holding areas.
sent_43: At one of the sites the SMM recorded that two self-propelled howitzers (2S1 Gvozdika , 122mm) were missing.
sent_44: At the second site the SMM observed two multiple launch rocket systems (MLRS, BM-21 Grad , 122mm) were missing, as they had been during the previous visit on 5 April (see SMM Daily Report 7 April ).
sent_45: The SMM visited on the same day two Ukrainian Armed Forces heavy weapons holding areas, which were found empty.
sent_46: The SMM had previously recorded eight self-propelled howitzers (2S3 Akatsiya , 152mm) at one site and four self-propelled howitzers (2S1) at the second.
sent_47: The military commander present at the first site told the SMM that the weapons were redeployed to another specified location on the previous day.
sent_48: At the second site the SMM learned from several civilian interlocutors that the military removed the weapons from the site a few days prior to the visit.
sent_49: In violation of the respective withdrawal lines, the SMM unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) spotted 11 tanks (type unknown) in the area of “DPR”-controlled Sontseve (56km south-east of Donetsk).
sent_5: At the Joint Centre for Control and Co-ordination (JCCC) observation point at “Donetsk People’s Republic” (“DPR”)-controlled Donetsk railway station (8km north-west of Donetsk city centre), the SMM recorded on 26 September three instances of ceasefire violations between 11:28 and 13:34hrs.
sent_50: The SMM observed military movement in areas beyond the respective withdrawal lines.
sent_51: The SMM UAV observed on 26 September five tanks in the “DPR”-controlled area of Komsomolske (43km south-east of Donetsk).
sent_52: Both on 26 and 27 September the SMM UAV spotted a concentration of at least 50 tanks and other military hardware in a training area south of “DPR”-controlled Torez (61km east of Donetsk).
sent_53: On 26 September the SMM observed at least 36 tanks (type unknown) at the training area in “LPR”-controlled Kruhlyk (31km south-west of Luhansk).
sent_54: A day earlier the SMM spotted at the same training area one heavy multiple launch thermobaric rocket system (TOS-1 Buratino , 220mm).
sent_55: In the area of government-controlled Novookhtyrka (53km north-west of Luhansk)  the SMM noted a convoy consisting of three main battle tanks (T-72) transported on trailers, and one infantry fighting vehicle (IFV, BMP-2) moving east.
sent_56: On 27 September the SMM noted a military convoy in the area of government-controlled Artemivsk (66km north-east of Donetsk), which contained six self-propelled howitzers (2S1), one armoured personnel carrier (APC), and one military truck transporting troops to a north-west direction.
sent_57: Also on 27 September the SMM observed another convoy consisting of four IFVs (BMP), and three towed howitzers (D-30) moving north away from Artemivsk on the M03 highway.
sent_58: On 27 September the SMM noted a convoy of six tracked APCs (type unknown) moving east, in the area of government-controlled Plotyna (28km north-east of Luhansk).
sent_59: On the same day the SMM observed at the training area near “LPR”-controlled Uspenka (23km south-west of Luhansk) a number of heavy artillery pieces, including 12 towed howitzers (D-30, 122mm), and 13 self-propelled howitzers (2S1), an increase comparing to previous SMM observation (see SMM Daily Report 25 September ).
sent_6: [1] The Ukrainian Armed Forces representatives at the JCCC present at the observation point suggested the explosions were likely part of “DPR” training activities.
sent_60: The SMM continued to monitor the situation at the crossing points to Crimea – Kalanchak, Chaplynka, and Chonhar (95, 90, and 162km south-east of Kherson , respectively) – which remained relatively calm and stable.
sent_61: Activists randomly checked vehicles and drivers’ documents at their improvised check-points, which are now installed a few kilometres away from the three Ukrainian border guards crossing points.
sent_62: At the activists’ improvised checkpoint some 2km away from the Kalanchak crossing point, a protester who introduced herself as the Pravyi Sektor’s Press Officer told the SMM that the vehicle drivers and passengers did not object to car searches when approached by activists, and “showed their understanding of the blockade”.
sent_63: At Chonhar, another Pravyi Sektor activist told the SMM on 27 September that less than a quarter of the drivers passing the ‘blockade’ were contesting the activists’ efforts to conduct vehicle searches.
sent_64: On 27 September the SMM followed up with the Odessa Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) and the Odessa regional police on the explosion that occurred at the headquarters of the Odessa SBU office earlier the same day.
sent_65: The police confirmed that an unidentified explosive device in the equivalent of at least 5 kg of trinitrotoluene (TNT) had been placed near the back door of the SBU building and exploded at 04:45hrs.
sent_66: The SBU interlocutor told the SMM that nobody had been injured in the detonation, and that an investigation had been initiated under the “terrorism” article of Ukraine’s Criminal Code.
sent_67: The SMM continued to monitor the situation in Kharkiv , Dnepropetrovsk , Chernivtsi , Ivano-Frankivsk , Lviv and Kyiv .
sent_68: *Restrictions on SMM monitoring, access and freedom of movement:
sent_69: The SMM is restrained in fulfilling its monitoring functions by restrictions imposed by the parties and security considerations, including mine threats, and damaged infrastructure.
sent_7: On 27 September the SMM heard six explosions consistent with outgoing mortar or artillery fire, as well as small-arms and heavy-machine-gun fire some 1.5-2km east of its position at a filling station in government-controlled Opytne (61km north-east of Donetsk).
sent_70: The security situation in Donbas is fluid and unpredictable and the ceasefire does not hold everywhere.
sent_71: Self-imposed restrictions on movement into high-risk areas have impinged on SMM patrolling activities, particularly in some areas not controlled by the government.
sent_72: Members of the “LPR” continue to prevent the SMM from monitoring in some areas close to the border with the Russian Federation .
sent_73: Denied access: On 26 September the armed personnel at a “DPR” “traffic police” checkpoint stopped the SMM some 2km away from the Ternove shooting range, denying its passage without any explanation; On 27 September two “LPR” “border guards” stopped the SMM in “LPR”-controlled Velykyi Sukhodil (43km south-east of Luhansk), a town 1.5km away from the Ukraine-Russian Federation international border.
sent_74: The “LPR” members denied the SMM any further movement without a permit signed by the “LPR” leadership, demanded the SMM to leave the area, and escorted it out of town.
sent_75: Delayed access: During the visit of a “DPR” heavy weapons holding area on 26 September, the SMM was not allowed access to the site for 50 minutes, until the “DPR” guard received a phone call from his superior; The “DPR” armed members at a checkpoint near Ozeryanivka (32km north-east of Donetsk) delayed the SMM for 75 minutes, after which it only allowed its movement with an escort.
sent_76: Interference with the UAV: On 27 September, while flying over “DPR”-controlled areas north-east of government-controlled Mariupol (103km south-west of Donestk) a SMM UAV was jammed four times.
sent_8: The SMM enquired with an employee at the filling station who said there was a Ukrainian Armed Forces firing range in the area.
sent_9: In government-controlled Dzerzhynsk (41km north of Donetsk), the SMM talked on 26 September to the deputy commander of the Ukrainian Armed Forces battalion deployed to the area.
title: Latest from OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) to Ukraine based on information received as of 27 September 2015 - OSCE

sent_0: The SMM monitored the implementation of the “Package of measures for the implementation of the Minsk agreements”.
sent_1: Its monitoring was restricted by the parties and security considerations*.
sent_10: The interlocutor claimed that while the situation was calmer recently, his subordinates reported that “DPR” intelligence gathering and reconnaissance patrols in the area were contributing to a tense atmosphere.
sent_11: On 26 September the SMM observed a convoy consisting of 15 cargo trucks marked as humanitarian convoy belonging to the Rinat Akhmetov Foundation, which was leaving “DPR”-controlled Donetsk city travelling freely through the “DPR” checkpoint in a southern direction.
sent_12: The SMM also observed in Donetsk city five cargo trucks escorted by a “DPR” “military police” vehicle, moving west.
sent_13: In government-controlled Marinka (23km south-west of Donetsk) the SMM talked to several interlocutors, who expressed a strong opinion about the need for Ukrainian Armed Forces to open a passage across the contact line for the residents from the nearby villages to travel on the Kurakhove-Donetsk route.
sent_14: Following that the SMM discussed the issue with the civil-military co-operation officers of the Ukrainian Armed Forces in Marinka, who stated the Anti-Terrorist Operation Headquarters was considering the idea of opening the requested passage corridor.
sent_15: The SMM spoke to shop-owners in government-controlled Krasnohorivka (21km west of Donetsk) who indicated that they had to acquire from the city administration a permit with the list of products they were bringing through government checkpoints, and that there was a limit for the amount of goods per crossing.
sent_16: The deputy commander at the closest relevant government checkpoint near Heorhiivka (26km south-west of Donetsk) confirmed to the SMM that local businesses indeed had to obtain a permit in order to transport goods through the checkpoint.
sent_17: On 26 September the SMM observed long lines of civilian vehicles at armed checkpoints waiting to cross both into governmental-controlled and “DPR”-controlled areas.
sent_18: While driving on H20 highway the SMM recorded at a Ukrainian Armed Forces checkpoint near Berezove (31km south-west of Donetsk) a queue of 160 vehicles waiting to cross into government-controlled area.
sent_19: Approaching a government checkpoint near government-controlled Volnovakha (52km south-west of Donetsk) the SMM noted 90 vehicles waiting to cross into the governmental-controlled area, and 432 vehicles queued to move north, into the “DPR”-controlled area.
sent_2: The situation remained largely calm in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions with only sparse ceasefire violations recorded by the SMM.
sent_20: At a checkpoint near government-controlled Maiorsk (44km north of Donetsk) the SMM counted 370 vehicles waiting to enter the government-controlled area, while 16 buses, 300 pedestrians, and 30 vehicles were queued to enter the “DPR”-controlled area.
sent_21: At the government checkpoint near Zaitseve (50km north-east of Donetsk) the SMM observed at least 79 vehicles waiting to move into the “DPR”-controlled area and 373 vehicles waiting to travel into the government-controlled area.
sent_22: At the “Shakhtarski Zori” health resort in Proletarskyi district of “DPR”-controlled Donetsk city, the SMM observed on 27 September a civilian mini-van with Russian Federation Krasnodar region licence plates.
sent_23: The licence plate number was fixed on a factory-made frame carrying the Russian inscription “FSB of Russian Federation”.
sent_24: As the SMM was about to depart from the facility, a male wearing the Russian new-style camouflage uniform without  any rank, insignia or patches, came out of the resort building and took a photograph or video of the leaving SMM vehicle, and made written notes.

sent_4: The SMM recorded a small number of ceasefire violations in the Donetsk region, where the security situation was otherwise relatively calm.
sent_40: At one of the sites the “DPR” armed member on guard did not allow access to the SMM for 50 minutes, until receiving permission from his superiors.
sent_41: One anti-tank gun (MT-12 Rapira , 10mm) was missing at this location.
sent_42: On 27 September the SMM visited another two “DPR” heavy weapons holding areas.
sent_43: At one of the sites the SMM recorded that two self-propelled howitzers (2S1 Gvozdika , 122mm) were missing.
sent_44: At the second site the SMM observed two multiple launch rocket systems (MLRS, BM-21 Grad , 122mm) were missing, as they had been during the previous visit on 5 April (see SMM Daily Report 7 April ).
sent_45: The SMM visited on the same day two Ukrainian Armed Forces heavy weapons holding areas, which were found empty.
sent_46: The SMM had previously recorded eight self-propelled howitzers (2S3 Akatsiya , 152mm) at one site and four self-propelled howitzers (2S1) at the second.
sent_47: The military commander present at the first site told the SMM that the weapons were redeployed to another specified location on the previous day.
sent_48: At the second site the SMM learned from several civilian interlocutors that the military removed the weapons from the site a few days prior to the visit.
sent_49: In violation of the respective withdrawal lines, the SMM unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) spotted 11 tanks (type unknown) in the area of “DPR”-controlled Sontseve (56km south-east of Donetsk).
sent_5: At the Joint Centre for Control and Co-ordination (JCCC) observation point at “Donetsk People’s Republic” (“DPR”)-controlled Donetsk railway station (8km north-west of Donetsk city centre), the SMM recorded on 26 September three instances of ceasefire violations between 11:28 and 13:34hrs.
sent_50: The SMM observed military movement in areas beyond the respective withdrawal lines.
sent_51: The SMM UAV observed on 26 September five tanks in the “DPR”-controlled area of Komsomolske (43km south-east of Donetsk).
sent_52: Both on 26 and 27 September the SMM UAV spotted a concentration of at least 50 tanks and other military hardware in a training area south of “DPR”-controlled Torez (61km east of Donetsk).
sent_53: On 26 September the SMM observed at least 36 tanks (type unknown) at the training area in “LPR”-controlled Kruhlyk (31km south-west of Luhansk).
sent_54: A day earlier the SMM spotted at the same training area one heavy multiple launch thermobaric rocket system (TOS-1 Buratino , 220mm).
sent_55: In the area of government-controlled Novookhtyrka (53km north-west of Luhansk)  the SMM noted a convoy consisting of three main battle tanks (T-72) transported on trailers, and one infantry fighting vehicle (IFV, BMP-2) moving east.
sent_56: On 27 September the SMM noted a military convoy in the area of government-controlled Artemivsk (66km north-east of Donetsk), which contained six self-propelled howitzers (2S1), one armoured personnel carrier (APC), and one military truck transporting troops to a north-west direction.
sent_57: Also on 27 September the SMM observed another convoy consisting of four IFVs (BMP), and three towed howitzers (D-30) moving north away from Artemivsk on the M03 highway.
sent_58: On 27 September the SMM noted a convoy of six tracked APCs (type unknown) moving east, in the area of government-controlled Plotyna (28km north-east of Luhansk).
sent_59: On the same day the SMM observed at the training area near “LPR”-controlled Uspenka (23km south-west of Luhansk) a number of heavy artillery pieces, including 12 towed howitzers (D-30, 122mm), and 13 self-propelled howitzers (2S1), an increase comparing to previous SMM observation (see SMM Daily Report 25 September ).
sent_6: [1] The Ukrainian Armed Forces representatives at the JCCC present at the observation point suggested the explosions were likely part of “DPR” training activities.
sent_60: The SMM continued to monitor the situation at the crossing points to Crimea – Kalanchak, Chaplynka, and Chonhar (95, 90, and 162km south-east of Kherson , respectively) – which remained relatively calm and stable.
sent_61: Activists randomly checked vehicles and drivers’ documents at their improvised check-points, which are now installed a few kilometres away from the three Ukrainian border guards crossing points.
sent_62: At the activists’ improvised checkpoint some 2km away from the Kalanchak crossing point, a protester who introduced herself as the Pravyi Sektor’s Press Officer told the SMM that the vehicle drivers and passengers did not object to car searches when approached by activists, and “showed their understanding of the blockade”.
sent_63: At Chonhar, another Pravyi Sektor activist told the SMM on 27 September that less than a quarter of the drivers passing the ‘blockade’ were contesting the activists’ efforts to conduct vehicle searches.
sent_64: On 27 September the SMM followed up with the Odessa Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) and the Odessa regional police on the explosion that occurred at the headquarters of the Odessa SBU office earlier the same day.
sent_65: The police confirmed that an unidentified explosive device in the equivalent of at least 5 kg of trinitrotoluene (TNT) had been placed near the back door of the SBU building and exploded at 04:45hrs.
sent_66: The SBU interlocutor told the SMM that nobody had been injured in the detonation, and that an investigation had been initiated under the “terrorism” article of Ukraine’s Criminal Code.
sent_67: The SMM continued to monitor the situation in Kharkiv , Dnepropetrovsk , Chernivtsi , Ivano-Frankivsk , Lviv and Kyiv .
sent_68: *Restrictions on SMM monitoring, access and freedom of movement:
sent_69: The SMM is restrained in fulfilling its monitoring functions by restrictions imposed by the parties and security considerations, including mine threats, and damaged infrastructure.
sent_7: On 27 September the SMM heard six explosions consistent with outgoing mortar or artillery fire, as well as small-arms and heavy-machine-gun fire some 1.5-2km east of its position at a filling station in government-controlled Opytne (61km north-east of Donetsk).
sent_70: The security situation in Donbas is fluid and unpredictable and the ceasefire does not hold everywhere.
sent_71: Self-imposed restrictions on movement into high-risk areas have impinged on SMM patrolling activities, particularly in some areas not controlled by the government.
sent_72: Members of the “LPR” continue to prevent the SMM from monitoring in some areas close to the border with the Russian Federation .
sent_73: Denied access: On 26 September the armed personnel at a “DPR” “traffic police” checkpoint stopped the SMM some 2km away from the Ternove shooting range, denying its passage without any explanation; On 27 September two “LPR” “border guards” stopped the SMM in “LPR”-controlled Velykyi Sukhodil (43km south-east of Luhansk), a town 1.5km away from the Ukraine-Russian Federation international border.
sent_74: The “LPR” members denied the SMM any further movement without a permit signed by the “LPR” leadership, demanded the SMM to leave the area, and escorted it out of town.
sent_75: Delayed access: During the visit of a “DPR” heavy weapons holding area on 26 September, the SMM was not allowed access to the site for 50 minutes, until the “DPR” guard received a phone call from his superior; The “DPR” armed members at a checkpoint near Ozeryanivka (32km north-east of Donetsk) delayed the SMM for 75 minutes, after which it only allowed its movement with an escort.
sent_76: Interference with the UAV: On 27 September, while flying over “DPR”-controlled areas north-east of government-controlled Mariupol (103km south-west of Donestk) a SMM UAV was jammed four times.
sent_8: The SMM enquired with an employee at the filling station who said there was a Ukrainian Armed Forces firing range in the area.
sent_9: In government-controlled Dzerzhynsk (41km north of Donetsk), the SMM talked on 26 September to the deputy commander of the Ukrainian Armed Forces battalion deployed to the area.
title: Latest from OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) to Ukraine based on information received as of 27 September 2015 - OSCE

sent_0: The SMM monitored the implementation of the “Package of measures for the implementation of the Minsk agreements”.
sent_1: Its monitoring was restricted by the parties and security considerations*.
sent_10: The interlocutor claimed that while the situation was calmer recently, his subordinates reported that “DPR” intelligence gathering and reconnaissance patrols in the area were contributing to a tense atmosphere.
sent_11: On 26 September the SMM observed a convoy consisting of 15 cargo trucks marked as humanitarian convoy belonging to the Rinat Akhmetov Foundation, which was leaving “DPR”-controlled Donetsk city travelling freely through the “DPR” checkpoint in a southern direction.
sent_12: The SMM also observed in Donetsk city five cargo trucks escorted by a “DPR” “military police” vehicle, moving west.
sent_13: In government-controlled Marinka (23km south-west of Donetsk) the SMM talked to several interlocutors, who expressed a strong opinion about the need for Ukrainian Armed Forces to open a passage across the contact line for the residents from the nearby villages to travel on the Kurakhove-Donetsk route.
sent_14: Following that the SMM discussed the issue with the civil-military co-operation officers of the Ukrainian Armed Forces in Marinka, who stated the Anti-Terrorist Operation Headquarters was considering the idea of opening the requested passage corridor.
sent_15: The SMM spoke to shop-owners in government-controlled Krasnohorivka (21km west of Donetsk) who indicated that they had to acquire from the city administration a permit with the list of products they were bringing through government checkpoints, and that there was a limit for the amount of goods per crossing.
sent_16: The deputy commander at the closest relevant government checkpoint near Heorhiivka (26km south-west of Donetsk) confirmed to the SMM that local businesses indeed had to obtain a permit in order to transport goods through the checkpoint.
sent_17: On 26 September the SMM observed long lines of civilian vehicles at armed checkpoints waiting to cross both into governmental-controlled and “DPR”-controlled areas.
sent_18: While driving on H20 highway the SMM recorded at a Ukrainian Armed Forces checkpoint near Berezove (31km south-west of Donetsk) a queue of 160 vehicles waiting to cross into government-controlled area.
sent_19: Approaching a government checkpoint near government-controlled Volnovakha (52km south-west of Donetsk) the SMM noted 90 vehicles waiting to cross into the governmental-controlled area, and 432 vehicles queued to move north, into the “DPR”-controlled area.
sent_2: The situation remained largely calm in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions with only sparse ceasefire violations recorded by the SMM.
sent_20: At a checkpoint near government-controlled Maiorsk (44km north of Donetsk) the SMM counted 370 vehicles waiting to enter the government-controlled area, while 16 buses, 300 pedestrians, and 30 vehicles were queued to enter the “DPR”-controlled area.
sent_21: At the government checkpoint near Zaitseve (50km north-east of Donetsk) the SMM observed at least 79 vehicles waiting to move into the “DPR”-controlled area and 373 vehicles waiting to travel into the government-controlled area.
sent_22: At the “Shakhtarski Zori” health resort in Proletarskyi district of “DPR”-controlled Donetsk city, the SMM observed on 27 September a civilian mini-van with Russian Federation Krasnodar region licence plates.
sent_23: The licence plate number was fixed on a factory-made frame carrying the Russian inscription “FSB of Russian Federation”.
sent_24: As the SMM was about to depart from the facility, a male wearing the Russian new-style camouflage uniform without  any rank, insignia or patches, came out of the resort building and took a photograph or video of the leaving SMM vehicle, and made written notes.
sent_25: The SMM observed an overall calm security situation in the Luhansk region with few ceasefire violations.
sent_26: On 26 September, from a stationary position north of government-controlled Trokhizbenka (33km north-west of Luhansk), the SMM heard in short intervals a couple of small-arms shots, three undetermined explosions, and sounds of two outgoing 82mm mortar rounds.
sent_27: All sounds were assessed as originating from the nearby Ukrainian Armed Forces military training area, and the SMM was informed in advance by Ukrainian Armed Forces that live-fire exercises would be conducted at this specific training facility.
sent_28: During their interaction with the SMM both Ukrainian Armed Forces personnel and armed “Lugansk People’s Republic (“LPR”) members made mutual allegations of small-arms ceasefire violations.
sent_29: “LPR” members told the SMM that they were targeted on 25 September in the area of “LPR”-controlled Pryshyb (33km north-west of Luhansk), and Krasnyi Lyman (30km north-west of Luhansk).
sent_3: The SMM observed considerable queues of civilian vehicles waiting at checkpoints to cross both into government-controlled and non-government controlled areas.
sent_30: The Ukrainian Armed Forces interlocutors stated they came under fire at the checkpoint near government-controlled Troitske (69km west of Luhansk).
sent_31: On 27 September the SMM enquired on prices and the availability of goods at two trading places in “LPR”-controlled Luhansk city.
sent_32: While both markets were well equipped with food and sanitary items the SMM concluded that the cost of basic products increased by an average 5% during the month of September.
sent_33: The SMM interlocutors at the markets claimed that the rise in prices was owed to the fact that they had to pay at the checkpoints for transporting the supplies into “LPR”-controlled areas.
sent_34: The SMM observed that the Russian Rouble was used as the primary currency in the market transactions, rather than the Ukrainian Hryvnia.
sent_35: The SMM monitored on 26 September a local ceasefire regime, through which it facilitated power line repair works near “LPR”-controlled Obozne (18km north of Luhansk).
sent_36: The SMM heard two explosions occurring within an interval of three hours.
sent_37: A repair worker of the electrical company informed the SMM that a member of the “LPR” demining team had been injured by an anti-personnel mine in the first explosion, and transported to the hospital.
sent_38: The second explosion, according to the interlocutor, was a controlled detonation of unexploded ordnance (UXO) performed by the “LPR” demining team during the demining process that preceded the repairs.
sent_39: The SMM re-visited on 26 September three “DPR” heavy weapons holding areas.

sent_40: At one of the sites the “DPR” armed member on guard did not allow access to the SMM for 50 minutes, until receiving permission from his superiors.
sent_41: One anti-tank gun (MT-12 Rapira , 10mm) was missing at this location.
sent_42: On 27 September the SMM visited another two “DPR” heavy weapons holding areas.
sent_43: At one of the sites the SMM recorded that two self-propelled howitzers (2S1 Gvozdika , 122mm) were missing.
sent_44: At the second site the SMM observed two multiple launch rocket systems (MLRS, BM-21 Grad , 122mm) were missing, as they had been during the previous visit on 5 April (see SMM Daily Report 7 April ).
sent_45: The SMM visited on the same day two Ukrainian Armed Forces heavy weapons holding areas, which were found empty.
sent_46: The SMM had previously recorded eight self-propelled howitzers (2S3 Akatsiya , 152mm) at one site and four self-propelled howitzers (2S1) at the second.
sent_47: The military commander present at the first site told the SMM that the weapons were redeployed to another specified location on the previous day.
sent_48: At the second site the SMM learned from several civilian interlocutors that the military removed the weapons from the site a few days prior to the visit.
sent_49: In violation of the respective withdrawal lines, the SMM unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) spotted 11 tanks (type unknown) in the area of “DPR”-controlled Sontseve (56km south-east of Donetsk).

sent_53: On 26 September the SMM observed at least 36 tanks (type unknown) at the training area in “LPR”-controlled Kruhlyk (31km south-west of Luhansk).
sent_54: A day earlier the SMM spotted at the same training area one heavy multiple launch thermobaric rocket system (TOS-1 Buratino , 220mm).
sent_55: In the area of government-controlled Novookhtyrka (53km north-west of Luhansk)  the SMM noted a convoy consisting of three main battle tanks (T-72) transported on trailers, and one infantry fighting vehicle (IFV, BMP-2) moving east.
sent_56: On 27 September the SMM noted a military convoy in the area of government-controlled Artemivsk (66km north-east of Donetsk), which contained six self-propelled howitzers (2S1), one armoured personnel carrier (APC), and one military truck transporting troops to a north-west direction.
sent_57: Also on 27 September the SMM observed another convoy consisting of four IFVs (BMP), and three towed howitzers (D-30) moving north away from Artemivsk on the M03 highway.

sent_59: On the same day the SMM observed at the training area near “LPR”-controlled Uspenka (23km south-west of Luhansk) a number of heavy artillery pieces, including 12 towed howitzers (D-30, 122mm), and 13 self-propelled howitzers (2S1), an increase comparing to previous SMM observation (see SMM Daily Report 25 September ).

sent_52: Both on 26 and 27 September the SMM UAV spotted a concentration of at least 50 tanks and other military hardware in a training area south of “DPR”-controlled Torez (61km east of Donetsk).
sent_53: On 26 September the SMM observed at least 36 tanks (type unknown) at the training area in “LPR”-controlled Kruhlyk (31km south-west of Luhansk).
sent_54: A day earlier the SMM spotted at the same training area one heavy multiple launch thermobaric rocket system (TOS-1 Buratino , 220mm).
sent_55: In the area of government-controlled Novookhtyrka (53km north-west of Luhansk)  the SMM noted a convoy consisting of three main battle tanks (T-72) transported on trailers, and one infantry fighting vehicle (IFV, BMP-2) moving east.
sent_56: On 27 September the SMM noted a military convoy in the area of government-controlled Artemivsk (66km north-east of Donetsk), which contained six self-propelled howitzers (2S1), one armoured personnel carrier (APC), and one military truck transporting troops to a north-west direction.
sent_57: Also on 27 September the SMM observed another convoy consisting of four IFVs (BMP), and three towed howitzers (D-30) moving north away from Artemivsk on the M03 highway.
sent_58: On 27 September the SMM noted a convoy of six tracked APCs (type unknown) moving east, in the area of government-controlled Plotyna (28km north-east of Luhansk).
sent_59: On the same day the SMM observed at the training area near “LPR”-controlled Uspenka (23km south-west of Luhansk) a number of heavy artillery pieces, including 12 towed howitzers (D-30, 122mm), and 13 self-propelled howitzers (2S1), an increase comparing to previous SMM observation (see SMM Daily Report 25 September ).
sent_6: [1] The Ukrainian Armed Forces representatives at the JCCC present at the observation point suggested the explosions were likely part of “DPR” training activities.
sent_60: The SMM continued to monitor the situation at the crossing points to Crimea – Kalanchak, Chaplynka, and Chonhar (95, 90, and 162km south-east of Kherson , respectively) – which remained relatively calm and stable.
sent_61: Activists randomly checked vehicles and drivers’ documents at their improvised check-points, which are now installed a few kilometres away from the three Ukrainian border guards crossing points.
sent_62: At the activists’ improvised checkpoint some 2km away from the Kalanchak crossing point, a protester who introduced herself as the Pravyi Sektor’s Press Officer told the SMM that the vehicle drivers and passengers did not object to car searches when approached by activists, and “showed their understanding of the blockade”.
sent_63: At Chonhar, another Pravyi Sektor activist told the SMM on 27 September that less than a quarter of the drivers passing the ‘blockade’ were contesting the activists’ efforts to conduct vehicle searches.
sent_64: On 27 September the SMM followed up with the Odessa Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) and the Odessa regional police on the explosion that occurred at the headquarters of the Odessa SBU office earlier the same day.
sent_65: The police confirmed that an unidentified explosive device in the equivalent of at least 5 kg of trinitrotoluene (TNT) had been placed near the back door of the SBU building and exploded at 04:45hrs.
sent_66: The SBU interlocutor told the SMM that nobody had been injured in the detonation, and that an investigation had been initiated under the “terrorism” article of Ukraine’s Criminal Code.
sent_67: The SMM continued to monitor the situation in Kharkiv , Dnepropetrovsk , Chernivtsi , Ivano-Frankivsk , Lviv and Kyiv .
sent_68: *Restrictions on SMM monitoring, access and freedom of movement:
sent_69: The SMM is restrained in fulfilling its monitoring functions by restrictions imposed by the parties and security considerations, including mine threats, and damaged infrastructure.
sent_7: On 27 September the SMM heard six explosions consistent with outgoing mortar or artillery fire, as well as small-arms and heavy-machine-gun fire some 1.5-2km east of its position at a filling station in government-controlled Opytne (61km north-east of Donetsk).
sent_70: The security situation in Donbas is fluid and unpredictable and the ceasefire does not hold everywhere.
sent_71: Self-imposed restrictions on movement into high-risk areas have impinged on SMM patrolling activities, particularly in some areas not controlled by the government.
sent_72: Members of the “LPR” continue to prevent the SMM from monitoring in some areas close to the border with the Russian Federation .
sent_73: Denied access: On 26 September the armed personnel at a “DPR” “traffic police” checkpoint stopped the SMM some 2km away from the Ternove shooting range, denying its passage without any explanation; On 27 September two “LPR” “border guards” stopped the SMM in “LPR”-controlled Velykyi Sukhodil (43km south-east of Luhansk), a town 1.5km away from the Ukraine-Russian Federation international border.
sent_74: The “LPR” members denied the SMM any further movement without a permit signed by the “LPR” leadership, demanded the SMM to leave the area, and escorted it out of town.
sent_75: Delayed access: During the visit of a “DPR” heavy weapons holding area on 26 September, the SMM was not allowed access to the site for 50 minutes, until the “DPR” guard received a phone call from his superior; The “DPR” armed members at a checkpoint near Ozeryanivka (32km north-east of Donetsk) delayed the SMM for 75 minutes, after which it only allowed its movement with an escort.
sent_76: Interference with the UAV: On 27 September, while flying over “DPR”-controlled areas north-east of government-controlled Mariupol (103km south-west of Donestk) a SMM UAV was jammed four times.
sent_8: The SMM enquired with an employee at the filling station who said there was a Ukrainian Armed Forces firing range in the area.
sent_9: In government-controlled Dzerzhynsk (41km north of Donetsk), the SMM talked on 26 September to the deputy commander of the Ukrainian Armed Forces battalion deployed to the area.
title: Latest from OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) to Ukraine based on information received as of 27 September 2015 - OSCE

sent_0: The organizers of the Crimean referendum are pleased with the high voter turnout.
sent_1: It is seen as a beginning of the peninsula's unification with Russia.
sent_10: That is how they came up with the 1.5 million ballots that were printed for the referendum.
sent_11: "That's around one percent more than the number of voters," Malyshev adds.
sent_12: The official explanation for that discrepancy is that if voters don't vote the way they had intended to, they could have a replacement ballot card.
sent_13: Around 1.5 million ballots papers were printed for the referendum
sent_14: There were two questions on the ballot papers.
sent_15: Each question was printed in Russian, Ukrainian and Crimean Tatar, the languages of the biggest ethnic groups on the peninsula.
sent_16: The first question was clear enough: "Are you in favor of Crimea being united with Russia as a subject of the Russian Federation?"
sent_17: The second question was about Crimea remaining part of Ukraine with a small change to its status: "Are you in favor of reinstating the 1992 version of the Crimean Republic's constitution and of Crimea's status as a part of Ukraine?"
sent_18: The wording was referring to a constitution that granted Crimea a broadly autonomous status.
sent_19: It was written around the time of the fall of the Soviet Union but was abolished shortly after it was passed.
sent_2: Many voters in the capital Simferopol voted in favor of secession.
sent_20: Against 'fascists' and for stability
sent_21: Voters weren't given any clarification for the second question.
sent_22: For more than a week now, Crimeans haven't been able to receive Ukrainian analogue television stations.
sent_23: Russian stations are on air, however, and have been harshly criticizing the "nationalists" and "bandits" in Kyiv.
sent_24: Crimean Igor voted in favor of secession
sent_25: "Ukraine has betrayed us to fascists, and that is why I voted to join Russia," explains one young man, who says his name is Igor.
sent_26: An elderly couple - Arif, an Azeri, and Nina, a Russian - said they had voted for "more stability."
sent_27: They are in favor of Crimea joining Russia.
sent_28: "We all saw what was going on in Kyiv," Nina explained calmly.
sent_29: Enthusiasm and caution
sent_3: The beginning of the "historical day," as March 16 has been referred to in Crimea by those promoting the referendum to join the Russian Federation , didn't seem promising.
sent_30: Alla, a 40-something-year-old head of a vocational school, is convinced that "historic justice should win" - this is why she has voted for Russia.
sent_31: Crimea has always been Russian, she says.
sent_32: Now she believes everything will be better, because Russia, as opposed to Ukraine, has a good leader, according to her.
sent_33: Meanwhile, 36-year-old Andrey is more skeptical.
sent_34: "If Russia treats us like it does South Ossetia and Abkhazia, both of which have become poor, then we will put up resistance."
sent_35: Gennady, a young computer engineer is one of the few here to say that he voted for Crimea staying in Ukraine.
sent_36: "The development in our country has shown that we now have more influence on those in power," he explained.
sent_37: "In Russia there's hardly any freedom."
sent_38: Right-wing populist election observer
sent_39: Johann Gudenus, member of parliament in Vienna and member of the right-wing populist Freedom Party in Austria, has a different view.
sent_4: The previous night had been stormy and the morning saw rain over Simferopol, the capital of Crimea.
sent_40: He is one of a couple of dozen European MEPs who have been invited as observers by the organizers of the referendum.
sent_41: "Most European politicians pander to the US, and the US often interpret international law how it suits them best," he told DW.
sent_42: Gudenus only arrived in Crimea the day before the referendum.
sent_43: "I can only talk about what I've seen, and I can't see any evidence of pressure, propaganda or military influence."
sent_44: Looking at the streets of Simferopol, though, you can see plenty of billboards in favor of secession of Ukraine.
sent_45: There are no billboards at all against secession.
sent_46: Plus, the military is clearly visible in the streets.
sent_47: The organizers of the referendum were keen to avoid any kind of incident during the voting process.
sent_48: The Russian band 'Lyube' held a concert in Lenin Square in the city-center.
sent_49: The band is known for its patriotic songs.
sent_5: Ambiguity over voters and questions
sent_50: Putin is said to be a fan.
sent_51: Meanwhile, in a café near Lenin Square, a TV screen shows Robbie Williams singing Frank Sinatra's "My Way."
sent_52: This Sunday, Crimea is going to start finding its way.
sent_6: But despite the rain, the members of the hastily convened local electoral commission had a lot to do.
sent_7: The new leadership had given the commission exactly 10 days to organize the vote.
sent_8: Meanwhile, the government in Kyiv refused to hand over the relevant voter registers to Simferopol.
sent_9: "We used the data from the last vote," said election chairman Mikhail Malyshev.

sent_48: The Russian band 'Lyube' held a concert in Lenin Square in the city-center.
sent_49: The band is known for its patriotic songs.
sent_5: Ambiguity over voters and questions
sent_50: Putin is said to be a fan.
sent_51: Meanwhile, in a café near Lenin Square, a TV screen shows Robbie Williams singing Frank Sinatra's "My Way."
sent_52: This Sunday, Crimea is going to start finding its way.
sent_6: But despite the rain, the members of the hastily convened local electoral commission had a lot to do.
sent_7: The new leadership had given the commission exactly 10 days to organize the vote.
sent_8: Meanwhile, the government in Kyiv refused to hand over the relevant voter registers to Simferopol.
sent_9: "We used the data from the last vote," said election chairman Mikhail Malyshev.
title: Referendum day in Crimea's Simferopol

sent_0: Western and Central Ukraine, including Kyiv, as well the southern part of the country, remained calm.
sent_1: The situation continued to be tense in the Luhansk region and particularly tense in the Donetsk region.
sent_10: In Donetsk, leaflets by the so-called “People’s Republic of Donetsk” were distributed on 26 April, inviting citizens to participate in a referendum to be held on 11 May 2014 on the question of whether or not they support the proclamation of “state sovereignty” by the “Donetsk Peoples Republic”.
sent_11: On 27 April, two members of the Donetsk Special Monitoring Mission team were detained by a group of unarmed men at around 11.15 in Yenakiyeve (55 km northeast of Donetsk).
sent_12: They claimed to be part of the so-called People’s Militia of Donbas, which refuses to recognize the legitimacy of the central government.
sent_13: The monitors were taken afterwards to the City Administration building.
sent_14: The Special Monitoring Mission Head of Office in Kyiv reached out to the capturers and sent a letter re-confirming the identity of the monitors.
sent_15: The monitors were allowed to return to Donetsk around 14:45.
sent_16: At the same time, another Special Monitoring Mission team, upon receiving permission to enter the heavily barricaded police building in Horlivka (43 northeast of Donetsk), was approached by five heavily armed and partly masked individuals.
sent_17: The monitors were cross-examined, accused of espionage and held for a short period of time.
sent_18: After a brief discussion with the occupants, the team was able to leave the scene.
sent_19: The Special Monitoring Mission also visited and observed a small, unmanned roadblock in Horlivka.
sent_2: Two Special Monitoring Mission monitors were temporary detained by the so-called People’s Militia of Donbas in Yenakiveve (55 km northeast of Donetsk).
sent_20: The general situation around Makiyivka Administration building was assessed as quiet and stable.
sent_21: The teams noticed five different flags flying at half-mast: a Donetsk Republic, a Makiyivka, a  Soviet Airborne forces, a St. George and a Donbas People’s Militia flag.
sent_22: In front of the back entrance, there were six unarmed men, four of whom were wearing uniforms with no insignia.
sent_23: Around 11:20, the team arrived in Khartzysk (30 km east of Donetsk).
sent_24: The administration building was open with a passable barricade surrounding it.
sent_25: The general situation at the scene was calm.
sent_26: Also in Maryinka (34 km west of Donetsk) and Novohrodivka (56 km northwest of Donetsk) the security situation was assessed as calm and stable.
sent_27: The team noticed several roadblocks in the area, one of which was manned by representatives of the self-proclaimed Republic of Donetsk in camouflage clothing.
sent_28: The situation has remained calm in Dnepropetrovsk.
sent_29: According to the Deputy Head of the “Right Sector”, whom the team met, the decision to move the headquarters of the organization to Dnepropetrovsk aimed at facilitating faster and more effective support to the Ukrainian forces in repelling possible attacks by armed opponents of the central government.
sent_3: The situation in Sloviansk, where the military observers as well as accompanying Ukrainian military officers were taken captive, remains a source of concern.
sent_30: To date, around 300 “Right Sector” activists have moved to Dnepropetrovsk from other regions.
sent_31: The general situation remained largely unchanged in Kherson, Mykolaiv and the surrounding area.
sent_32: In Mykolaiv and in the region the team observed bolstering of the existing checkpoints with additional sandbags and tires.
sent_33: Also, more police wearing body armour as well as civil defence volunteers were observed in the area.
sent_34: In Odessa the situation at both the “7th Kilometre” and “2 Stolba” checkpoints at the main road junctions west of the city was calm following the explosion incident on 25 April at the “7th Kilometre” checkpoint.
sent_35: Armed traffic police (around the “7th Kilometre checkpoint”) and police (around the “2 Stolba” checkpoint) appeared to be more active in monitoring traffic around them.
sent_36: Several public meetings and gatherings in the city organized by different parties were held without major incidents.
sent_37: The overall situation in Chernivtsi, Ivano-Frankivsk , Lviv as well as in Kyiv was calm.
sent_38: The Chernivtsi team visited the border post in Porubne, where it observed co-operation between the border police and the local citizens belonging to the “Public Formation” volunteer group, composed of local residents.
sent_39: The Kyiv monitors met with Pavlo Hubariev (in Russian: Pavel Gubariev), self-proclaimed Donetsk governor, who had been detained in Donetsk on 6 March.
sent_4: In Kharkiv clashes between around 400 opponents and 500 to 600 supporters of a unitary Ukrainian state occurred.
sent_40: Hubariev stated that he had obtained sufficient legal assistance.
sent_41: However, he complained about initial harassment by the staff of the detention facility, which had ceased after the public was informed.
sent_42: Since 17 April he is on a hunger strike, which he intends to continue until the situation in eastern Ukraine changes.
sent_5: Police attempts to prevent the clashes between the two groups proved to be unsuccessful.
sent_6: Both protesting groups were joined by 15 to 20 cars with flags and people inside, some of them wearing masks.
sent_7: Conflicting versions were conveyed to the monitors as to which group started the provocations when supporters from both sides encountered each other in the city.
sent_8: The situation in Luhansk surrounding the occupied state security service (SBU) building remained relatively calm, despite reported movements of armed men around the area on 26 April.
sent_9: The situation in Donetsk remained particularly tense due to the continuing presence of armed opponents of the central Government occupying and barricading administrative buildings in the region.
title: Latest from the Special Monitoring Mission in Ukraine – based on information received up until 27 April 2014

event: Annexation of Crimea;2014 Pro-Russian Unrest in Ukraine;Russian Military Intervention (Post-Euromaidan);
sent_0: The annual special Direct Line with Vladimir Putin was broadcast live by Channel One, Rossiya-1 and Rossiya-24 TV channels, and Mayak, Vesti FM and Radio Rossii radio stations.
sent_1: Especially popular in the course of the discussion were questions about Crimea, including the socioeconomic situation in Russia’s new regions – the Crimean Republic and Sevastopol, the development of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet, and the situation regarding the Crimean Tatars.
sent_10: Here in the studio today are Maria Sittel and Kirill Kleymenov.
sent_11: Direct line programme host Maria Sittel: Good afternoon, I could say that we are having today yet another conversation with Vladimir Putin, however the situation is different since the country we are talking to now has changed.
sent_12: After waiting for 23 years, since the breakup of the Soviet Union, Crimea and Sevastopol have joined Russia.
sent_13: For this reason, every question today will be directly or indirectly related to Crimea.
sent_14: We will discuss a number of issues today, including healthcare, army, taxes, agriculture and, naturally, Ukraine.
sent_15: There is no doubt that we’ll discuss developments in Ukraine’s southeast and the genocide that was unleashed in this region.

sent_10: “We are not the experts to determine the signature of this action plan.

sent_13: It seems to me that this action plan is quite authentic,” Yatseniuk said.

sent_15: The  14-page document , the authenticity of which cannot be verified, says that the eventual membership of Ukraine to the Russian-sponsored Customs Union would bring additional trade exchange to the volume of $9 billion (€6.7 billion), while the proposed EU-Ukraine free-trade agreement would worsen Kyiv’s trade balance by $1.5 billion (€1.12 billion).
sent_16: This largely corresponds to a recent statement by Russian presidential advisor Sergei Glyazev, who said that signing the free trade agreement with the EU would be “suicidal” for Ukraine.
sent_17: The paper indicates that Russia will deploy all efforts to prevent Ukraine from signing the EU pact, and that it will strongly back pro-Russian candidate Viktor Medvedchuk at the 2015 presidential election.
sent_18: ‘Ukrainian Choice’, the political party of Medvedchuk, is envisaged to play a leading role in promoting the country’s accession to the Customs Union.
sent_19: Indeed, over a recent visit to Ukraine, Putin reportedly spent only 15 minutes in a meeting with his counterpart Yanukovich, but attended a long event hosted by Medvedchuk.

sent_20: Among the measures envisaged in the paper is “neutralising the media impact” of pro-European forces in Ukraine by supporting opinion makers who are favourable to Russia, as well as "sanctioning” pro-European Ukrainian oligarchs.
sent_21: The goal is for Ukraine to join the Customs Union in 2015, according to the document.
sent_22: The paper also envisions that pro-European civil servants in Ukraine institutions, especially in the ministry of foreign affairs and the ministry of defence, “who are de facto agents for Euro-Atlantic influence”, should be “discredited” and not allowed to remain in office after the presidential election.
sent_23: The paper also advises that President of Belarus Alexander Lukashenko should put pressure on his Ukrainian counterpart Viktor Yanukovych and convince him to turn to Moscow, as EU leaders "don't like him anyway".
sent_24: However, recent developments between Russia and Belarus would most likely discourage any country to join the Customs Union.
sent_25: Tension between Russia and Belarus rose yesterday, as Moscow warned oil supply cuts to its energy-poor neighbour could last for months, and Minsk threatened to open a criminal case against a Russian tycoon with Kremlin ties.
